title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, with no double benefit allowed for expenses eligible for other deductions or credits. No credit allowed for expenses eligible for other deductions or grants received. Qualified adoption expenses include adoption fees, court costs, and attorney fees directly related to the legal adoption of a child. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' refers to necessary fees and costs directly related to the legal adoption of a child, excluding expenses for adopting a spouse's child. Married couples must file joint returns for this purpose. The text discusses the inclusion of adoption expenses for a child who is not the spouse's child, and the requirement for married couples to file joint returns for this purpose. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate these rules. The text discusses adoption assistance for federal employees, including reimbursement for adoption expenses. The effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 1995. The text outlines adoption benefits for federal employees, defining terms such as 'agency' and 'adoption expenses'. The text outlines adoption expenses for federal employees, including fees charged by adoption agencies, legal fees, medical expenses, and transportation expenses. Each agency must establish a program for employees who adopt a child. The regulations require federal agencies to establish a program for reimbursing employees for adoption expenses, including fees charged by adoption agencies, legal fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Reimbursement is provided after the adoption becomes final, the child is under 18 years old and unmarried, and the employee files a written application with the necessary information. Reimbursement for an employee under this section is payable if the child is under 18 years old, unmarried, and adoption expenses are not fully covered by other programs, with a maximum limit of $2,000. Reimbursement under this section is payable if adoption expenses are not fully covered by other programs, with a maximum limit of $2,000 per parent if both are eligible employees. No payment will exceed the total amount payable to adoptive parents under this section and other programs. The reimbursement under this section has a maximum limit of $4,000 to adoptive parents, with guidelines for interagency cooperation. Payments are made from the same fund as the employee's salary, and marital status cannot be a basis for denial of reimbursement. The Office of Personnel Management has the authority to issue general guidelines. The Office of Personnel Management may issue guidelines for uniform administration of reimbursement under this section, and agencies must follow these guidelines. The Office can also provide assistance to agencies upon request for implementing this section. Section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to apply Section 9001 of title 5 to the Postal Service. Regulations must be consistent with guidelines issued under subsection (g)(1) of such section. Section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to apply Section 9001 of title 5 to the Postal Service. This amendment will take effect on October 1, 1995, and will apply to adoptions finalized on or after that date. Additionally, Title III excludes adoption assistance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employee adoption assistance benefits and military adoption assistance benefits received by an employee for adopting a child are not included in the employee's gross income. Employee adoption assistance benefits refer to payments by an employer for qualified adoption expenses, while military adoption assistance benefits are benefits provided to military personnel for adoption. Qualified adoption expenses are defined as reasonable and necessary fees directly related to the legal adoption of an eligible child by the taxpayer. The term 'expenses' refers to adoption fees, court costs, attorney fees, and other expenses directly related to the legal adoption of an eligible child by the taxpayer. An 'eligible child' is defined as an individual under 18 years old or someone who is physically or mentally incapable of self-care. The Secretary will issue regulations to coordinate this section with other provisions allowing a credit or deduction for qualified adoption expenses. The amendments made to Sec. 137 and Sec. 138 regarding adoption assistance and cross references to other Acts will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
